propositions.text: The Community MusicWorks Center in Providence, Rhode Island, is a mass timber project
propositions.sourceText:
**Project Name:** Community MusicWorks Center
**Location:** Providence, Rhode Island
**Size:** 24,000 square feet
**Architect:** 3SIX0 Architects
**Contractor:** Pezzuco Construction Inc
**Structural Engineer:** WSP USA Buildings Inc.
**Acoustic Consultant:** ARUP
**Supplier:** Element5 | HASSLACHER Group
**Timber Products:** CLT, Glulam, Light-frame panels

propositions.text: The Community MusicWorks Center in Providence, Rhode Island, was built almost entirely from cross-laminated timber (CLT) and glulam
propositions.sourceText: When a visionary music nonprofit for youth in Providence, Rhode Island, set out to build a single dedicated facility, the architects at 3SIX0 responded with a crystalline structure at the intersection of two city grids—and built almost entirely from cross-laminated timber (CLT) and glulam<sup>1</sup>. More than just an innovative structural...

propositions.text: Concrete and steel were initially assumed to be the most affordable construction systems for the Community MusicWorks Center project
propositions.sourceText: Though concrete and steel were initially assumed to be the most affordable construction systems, 3SIX0 and CMW soon shifted to a less obvious option: CLT. “Wood was in the air, but it was certainly not a foregone conclusion when we started,” Leski says. “This was always a budget-constrained project, always....

propositions.text: Initial budget numbers for the Community MusicWorks Center project assumed it would be more affordable to build with conventional concrete and steel
propositions.sourceText: Though concrete and steel were initially assumed to be the most affordable construction systems, 3SIX0 and CMW soon shifted to a less obvious option: CLT. “Wood was in the air, but it was certainly not a foregone conclusion when we started,” Leski says. “This was always a budget-constrained project, always....

propositions.text: Cross-laminated timber (CLT) aligned with the atmosphere Community MusicWorks hoped to create for their center
propositions.sourceText: **New Post:** This mass timber music center in Providence hits all the right notes! Community MusicWorks' new CLT structure by @3SIX0 Architecture proves wood construction can create perfect acoustics while building community. See how their design transforms this community hub where structure and sound harmonize beautifully.

propositions.text: Cross-laminated timber (CLT) could serve as a finished surface throughout the Community MusicWorks Center
propositions.sourceText: When a visionary music nonprofit for youth in Providence, Rhode Island, set out to build a single dedicated facility, the architects at 3SIX0 responded with a crystalline structure at the intersection of two city grids—and built almost entirely from cross-laminated timber (CLT) and glulam<sup>1</sup>. More than just an innovative structural...

propositions.text: Chris Bardt, principal at 3SIX0 Architecture, sees wood as a warm and friendly material
propositions.sourceText: “We see wood as a warm and friendly material,” Bardt says. “Providence is made from wood. The community is somewhat resistant to overly modern architecture, but they have a place in their heart for wood.”

propositions.text: Chris Bardt, principal at 3SIX0 Architecture, notes that Providence, Rhode Island, is made from wood

propositions.text: Wood offered acoustic benefits for the Community MusicWorks Center project
propositions.sourceText:
**Project Name:** Community MusicWorks Center
**Location:** Providence, Rhode Island
**Size:** 24,000 square feet
**Architect:** 3SIX0 Architects
**Contractor:** Pezzuco Construction Inc
**Structural Engineer:** WSP USA Buildings Inc.
**Acoustic Consultant:** ARUP
**Supplier:** Element5 | HASSLACHER Group
**Timber Products:** CLT, Glulam, Light-frame panels

propositions.text: Chris Bardt, principal at 3SIX0 Architecture, states that wood has beautiful resonance, unlike brick (dead) or glass (sharp)
propositions.sourceText: Beyond cultural resonance, the material also offered acoustic benefits. “Wood has this beautiful resonance—it’s not dead like brick and not sharp like glass,” Bardt continues. “It creates a warmth that feels right for a place built around sound and music. That resonance has to be shaped and controlled.”

propositions.text: Chris Bardt, principal at 3SIX0 Architecture, states that wood creates a warmth that feels right for a place built around sound and music
propositions.sourceText: Beyond cultural resonance, the material also offered acoustic benefits. “Wood has this beautiful resonance—it’s not dead like brick and not sharp like glass,” Bardt continues. “It creates a warmth that feels right for a place built around sound and music. That resonance has to be shaped and controlled.”

propositions.text: The resonance of wood had to be shaped and controlled in the Community MusicWorks Center project
propositions.sourceText: # Mass Timber Project Profile: Community MusicWorks Center

propositions.text: The performance space in the Community MusicWorks Center vibrates with the energy of sound, thanks to the cross-laminated timber (CLT) and wood cladding
propositions.sourceText: When a visionary music nonprofit for youth in Providence, Rhode Island, set out to build a single dedicated facility, the architects at 3SIX0 responded with a crystalline structure at the intersection of two city grids—and built almost entirely from cross-laminated timber (CLT) and glulam<sup>1</sup>. More than just an innovative structural...

propositions.text: Every room in the Community MusicWorks Center, other than the central performance hall, needed some level of acoustic isolation to avoid sound transference into the performance spaces and vice versa
propositions.sourceText: The acoustical considerations also extend beyond the central hall. “The performance space is very alive—it vibrates with the energy of sound, thanks to the CLT and wood cladding,” Leski says. But every other room needed some level of acoustic isolation to avoid sound transference into the performance spaces, and vice...

propositions.text: To achieve acoustic isolation in the Community MusicWorks Center, the team implemented double-wall construction
propositions.sourceText: The acoustical considerations also extend beyond the central hall. “The performance space is very alive—it vibrates with the energy of sound, thanks to the CLT and wood cladding,” Leski says. But every other room needed some level of acoustic isolation to avoid sound transference into the performance spaces, and vice...

propositions.text: To achieve acoustic isolation in the Community MusicWorks Center, the team poured a light concrete topping on the cross-laminated timber (CLT) floors
propositions.sourceText: The acoustical considerations also extend beyond the central hall. “The performance space is very alive—it vibrates with the energy of sound, thanks to the CLT and wood cladding,” Leski says. But every other room needed some level of acoustic isolation to avoid sound transference into the performance spaces, and vice...

propositions.text: To achieve acoustic isolation in the Community MusicWorks Center, the team introduced rubber separators between assemblies
propositions.sourceText: The acoustical considerations also extend beyond the central hall. “The performance space is very alive—it vibrates with the energy of sound, thanks to the CLT and wood cladding,” Leski says. But every other room needed some level of acoustic isolation to avoid sound transference into the performance spaces, and vice...

propositions.text: Arup worked with the project team to treat the performance hall in the Community MusicWorks Center like an instrument
propositions.sourceText: “Working with Arup, we treated the performance hall like an instrument,” Leski says. “Each surface was tuned to reflect, diffuse, or absorb sound.” The result is architecture that sounds as good as it looks.

propositions.text: Each surface in the performance hall of the Community MusicWorks Center was tuned to reflect, diffuse, or absorb sound
propositions.sourceText: “Working with Arup, we treated the performance hall like an instrument,” Leski says. “Each surface was tuned to reflect, diffuse, or absorb sound.” The result is architecture that sounds as good as it looks.

propositions.text: Alban Bassuet, Associate Principal and Acoustical Engineering Consultant at Arup’s acoustics lab, states that wood is a very good material for music and acoustics because it resonates and vibrates with a more random distribution of frequency
propositions.sourceText: “When it comes to music and acoustics, wood is a very good material because it resonates and vibrates with a more random distribution of frequency. That’s what makes music so beautiful,” explains Alban Bassuet, Associate Principal and Acoustical Engineering Consultant at Arup’s acoustics lab.

propositions.text: In the performance hall of the Community MusicWorks Center, an optimization algorithm tested thousands of combinations of angled wood panels (concave, convex, and flat) to find the best arrangement for acoustics
propositions.sourceText: “In the performance hall, we ran an optimization algorithm that tested thousands of combinations of angled wood panels—concave, convex, and flat—to find the best arrangement for acoustics. And we raised the ceiling of the room as much as we could to reduce sound intensity.”

propositions.text: The ceiling of the performance hall in the Community MusicWorks Center was raised as much as possible to reduce sound intensity
propositions.sourceText: “In the performance hall, we ran an optimization algorithm that tested thousands of combinations of angled wood panels—concave, convex, and flat—to find the best arrangement for acoustics. And we raised the ceiling of the room as much as we could to reduce sound intensity.”

propositions.text: Wood comes with challenges, specifically controlling for vibration and sound isolation
propositions.sourceText: Nonetheless, wood comes with some challenges—specifically controlling for vibration and sound isolation. “We had to very carefully design all of the floors and ceilings to make sure adjacent activities would not disrupt other rooms. To achieve this in the practice rooms we built rooms within the CLT structure—a partial box-in-box...

propositions.text: Floors and ceilings in the Community MusicWorks Center had to be very carefully designed to ensure adjacent activities would not disrupt other rooms
propositions.sourceText: Nonetheless, wood comes with some challenges—specifically controlling for vibration and sound isolation. “We had to very carefully design all of the floors and ceilings to make sure adjacent activities would not disrupt other rooms. To achieve this in the practice rooms we built rooms within the CLT structure—a partial box-in-box...

propositions.text: To achieve sound isolation in the practice rooms of the Community MusicWorks Center, rooms were built within the cross-laminated timber (CLT) structure using a partial box-in-box system
propositions.sourceText: Nonetheless, wood comes with some challenges—specifically controlling for vibration and sound isolation. “We had to very carefully design all of the floors and ceilings to make sure adjacent activities would not disrupt other rooms. To achieve this in the practice rooms we built rooms within the CLT structure—a partial box-in-box...

propositions.text: A partial box-in-box system was used as a relatively cost-effective isolation design strategy for the practice rooms in the Community MusicWorks Center
propositions.sourceText: Nonetheless, wood comes with some challenges—specifically controlling for vibration and sound isolation. “We had to very carefully design all of the floors and ceilings to make sure adjacent activities would not disrupt other rooms. To achieve this in the practice rooms we built rooms within the CLT structure—a partial box-in-box...

propositions.text: While all-mass-timber structures often take straightforward, orthogonal forms, the material can also tackle relatively complex geometries like the Community MusicWorks Center design
propositions.sourceText: While all-mass-timber structures often take straightforward, orthogonal forms, the material can also tackle relatively complex geometries like CMW’s design. That challenge, as Leski explains, revealed new possibilities for the material’s versatility—particularly in civic projects of this scale.

propositions.text: The challenge of the Community MusicWorks Center's complex geometry revealed new possibilities for the versatility of mass timber materials, particularly in civic projects of this scale
propositions.sourceText: While all-mass-timber structures often take straightforward, orthogonal forms, the material can also tackle relatively complex geometries like CMW’s design. That challenge, as Leski explains, revealed new possibilities for the material’s versatility—particularly in civic projects of this scale.

propositions.text: The design of the Community MusicWorks Center initially envisioned a pure cross-laminated timber (CLT) structure
propositions.sourceText: When a visionary music nonprofit for youth in Providence, Rhode Island, set out to build a single dedicated facility, the architects at 3SIX0 responded with a crystalline structure at the intersection of two city grids—and built almost entirely from cross-laminated timber (CLT) and glulam<sup>1</sup>. More than just an innovative structural...

propositions.text: The design of the Community MusicWorks Center evolved into a hybrid system
propositions.sourceText: Initially envisioned as a pure CLT structure, the design evolved into a hybrid system—CLT slabs supported by glulam beams and columns. “Combining CLT and glulam with panelized light-frame wood construction kept things more affordable and also gave us greater flexibility,” Leski says. “And the quirks of the building’s geometry gave...

propositions.text: The hybrid system used in the Community MusicWorks Center consists of cross-laminated timber (CLT) slabs supported by glulam beams and columns
propositions.sourceText: Initially envisioned as a pure CLT structure, the design evolved into a hybrid system—CLT slabs supported by glulam beams and columns. “Combining CLT and glulam with panelized light-frame wood construction kept things more affordable and also gave us greater flexibility,” Leski says. “And the quirks of the building’s geometry gave...

propositions.text: Combining cross-laminated timber (CLT) and glulam with panelized light-frame wood construction kept the Community MusicWorks Center project more affordable
propositions.sourceText: Initially envisioned as a pure CLT structure, the design evolved into a hybrid system—CLT slabs supported by glulam beams and columns. “Combining CLT and glulam with panelized light-frame wood construction kept things more affordable and also gave us greater flexibility,” Leski says. “And the quirks of the building’s geometry gave...

propositions.text: Combining cross-laminated timber (CLT) and glulam with panelized light-frame wood construction gave the Community MusicWorks Center project greater flexibility
propositions.sourceText: Initially envisioned as a pure CLT structure, the design evolved into a hybrid system—CLT slabs supported by glulam beams and columns. “Combining CLT and glulam with panelized light-frame wood construction kept things more affordable and also gave us greater flexibility,” Leski says. “And the quirks of the building’s geometry gave...

propositions.text: Cross-laminated timber (CLT) is inherently planar
propositions.sourceText: When a visionary music nonprofit for youth in Providence, Rhode Island, set out to build a single dedicated facility, the architects at 3SIX0 responded with a crystalline structure at the intersection of two city grids—and built almost entirely from cross-laminated timber (CLT) and glulam<sup>1</sup>. More than just an innovative structural...

propositions.text: The planar nature of cross-laminated timber (CLT) helped shape how the Community MusicWorks Center building was thought about, as a kind of porous structure with a geometric rhythm
propositions.sourceText: What might have been a limitation became a defining feature. “CLT is inherently planar, and that helped shape how we thought about the building—as a kind of porous structure with a geometric rhythm to it. The movement through the building is musical: align, shift, pause, repeat,” Bardt says. “If you...

propositions.text: The walls of the performance hall in the Community MusicWorks Center are lined with exposed two-by-fours
propositions.sourceText: Even the performance hall’s interior finishes echo the project’s ethos. The walls are lined with exposed two-by-fours—simple, stick-frame construction, intentionally rough and rhythmic. “It almost evokes the idea of something under construction, not yet complete,” Leski explains. “This reflects that Community MusicWorks is a building of a community. It’s an...

propositions.text: The exposed two-by-fours lining the performance hall walls in the Community MusicWorks Center represent simple, stick-frame construction
propositions.sourceText: Even the performance hall’s interior finishes echo the project’s ethos. The walls are lined with exposed two-by-fours—simple, stick-frame construction, intentionally rough and rhythmic. “It almost evokes the idea of something under construction, not yet complete,” Leski explains. “This reflects that Community MusicWorks is a building of a community. It’s an...

propositions.text: The exposed two-by-fours lining the performance hall walls in the Community MusicWorks Center are intentionally rough and rhythmic
propositions.sourceText: Even the performance hall’s interior finishes echo the project’s ethos. The walls are lined with exposed two-by-fours—simple, stick-frame construction, intentionally rough and rhythmic. “It almost evokes the idea of something under construction, not yet complete,” Leski explains. “This reflects that Community MusicWorks is a building of a community. It’s an...

propositions.text: The abundant use of wood, exposed and textural, in the Community MusicWorks Center is both an aesthetic and philosophical gesture
propositions.sourceText: The abundant use of wood, exposed and textural, is both an aesthetic and philosophical gesture. “The rawness as a design language continues through, even in the most finished space,” Bardt adds. “What you see—exposed wood, unfinished edges, structural rhythm—reflects a philosophy.”

propositions.text: The rawness as a design language continues through, even in the most finished space of the Community MusicWorks Center
propositions.sourceText: The abundant use of wood, exposed and textural, is both an aesthetic and philosophical gesture. “The rawness as a design language continues through, even in the most finished space,” Bardt adds. “What you see—exposed wood, unfinished edges, structural rhythm—reflects a philosophy.”

propositions.text: What is seen in the Community MusicWorks Center—exposed wood, unfinished edges, structural rhythm—reflects a philosophy
propositions.sourceText: The abundant use of wood, exposed and textural, is both an aesthetic and philosophical gesture. “The rawness as a design language continues through, even in the most finished space,” Bardt adds. “What you see—exposed wood, unfinished edges, structural rhythm—reflects a philosophy.”

propositions.text: The exterior of the Community MusicWorks Center features horizontal, responsibly sourced Ipe cladding
propositions.sourceText: Outside, the building’s geometry continues the theme of angular motion and musical pacing with horizontal, responsibly sourced Ipe cladding. “There is a sense of movement and rhythm as you approach the building,” Bardt says, “very much like music.”
